Deputy Kovacs produces another document which he hands to Zero. Zero studies it as Deputy Kovacs continues:

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: They include, essentially, all members of the extended family -- but the key witness who actually (ostensibly) saw the alleged events appears to have fled the jurisdiction. His whereabouts are (more)  48. DEPUTY KOVACS (cont'd) currently unknown, but he’s being sought and pursued by the relevant authorities.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (concerned) Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: M. Gustave with a look of utter astonishment on his face. He blurts out:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Serge?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: That little prick. Pause. M. Gustave reconsiders.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: No, I don’t believe it. They put him up to it. I’ve been dropped into a nest of vipers.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: You have an alibi?

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (off-hand) Certainly, but she’s married to the Duke of Westfalia. I can’t allow her name to get mixed-up in all this monkey business.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (gravely) M. Gustave: your life may be at stake.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (bitterly) I know, but the bitch legged it. She’s already on the Queen Nasstasja half-way to Dutch Tanganyika. M. Gustave sighs and stares at the floor, shaking his head. He looks like he is about to cry. Zero says finally -- almost inaudibly:

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: Don't give up. M. Gustave looks back to Zero. He nods. He points.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: What’s in the box?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (encouraging) A Courtesan au chocolat.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (deeply moved) From Mendl’s. Thank you, my angel

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A dark lane crowded with narrow, crooked little buildings. Rushing water gurgles down the gutters. A pack of rats darts across the road in single-file and disappears into a drain-pipe. A church bell rings across the city. Jopling waits on the threshold of a ramshackle cottage staring at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The details of the conspiracy, now a matter of public record, were, at that time, impossible for us to apprehend. The door cracks open. A young washer-woman with a club foot and a rag in her hands peers out. Jopling hands the woman his card. She studies it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An engraved calling card on bright, white stock which reads: J.G. Jopling, Esq.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE INQUIRY AGENT
dialogues.text: The woman looks back up to Jopling, nervous. He says in a low voice:

dialogues.speaker: JOPLING
dialogues.text: I’m looking for Serge X. (a young man in the service of my employers, the family Desgoffe und Taxis of Schloss Lutz).

dialogues.speaker: WASHER-WOMAN
dialogues.text: (timidly) Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOPLING
dialogues.text: You're his sister?

dialogues.speaker: WASHER-WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  50.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLING
dialogues.text: Seen him lately?

dialogues.speaker: WASHER-WOMAN
dialogues.text: (surprised) No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLING
dialogues.text: (doubtful) No, sir?

dialogues.speaker: WASHER-WOMAN
dialogues.text: (innocent) No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLING
dialogues.text: I need to find him right away. For his own safety -- (pointing in her face) -- and everyone else’s. If he shows up?

dialogues.speaker: WASHER-WOMAN
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOPLING
dialogues.text: (darkly) Tell him Jopling says, “Come home.” Pause. The woman nods. Jopling turns away and walks over to a black motorcycle parked at the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- but one thing was certain: the Desgoffe und Taxis were a very powerful family -- Jopling puts on a pair of goggles, kick-starts his engine, revs the motor, and rumbles away. The woman shuts the door and locks the bolt.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Jopling racing his howling motorcycle through the center of the city at midnight. Under the goggles, his eyes are calm.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: and time was not on our side.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MESS HALL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Another evening meal. The full assembled staff sits at the long table, anxious and curious, murmuring. The cook waits, uncertain, gripping a cauldron by his oven-mitts. A door swings open.  51. Mr. Mosher and Zero stride into the room. Mr. Mosher holds up an envelope and beckons to Zero.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOSHER
dialogues.text: A letter from M. Gustave. Zero? The staff whispers excitedly then falls silent as Zero ascends M. Gustave’s podium, opens the envelope, and takes out a piece of paper. Pause. Zero clears his throat and reads in a formal voice:

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: “My dear and trusted colleagues --”

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: M. Gustave in his cell (where his podium seems to have been magically transported). A gentle halo of light glows behind him. He addresses the camera as he begins his usual pacing:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: -- I miss you deeply as I write from the confines of my regrettable and preposterous incarceration. Until I walk amongst you again as a free man, the Grand Budapest remains in your hands -- as does its impeccable reputation. Keep it spotless and glorify it. Take extra- special care of every little-bitty bit of it as if I were watching over you like a hawk with a horse-whip in its talons -- (brandishing a soup-ladle) -- because I am. Should I discover a lapse of any variety during my absence, I promise: swift and merciless justice will descend upon you. A great and noble house has been placed under your protection. (Tell Zero if you see any funny business.)

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zero at podium. He concludes:

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: “your devoted M. Gustave.” Then there’s a poem, but we might want to go ahead and start on the soup, since it’s forty-six stanzas. Mr. Mosher signals to the cook. He begins to serve as Zero reads on:  52.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: A moist, black ash dampens the filth of a dung-dark rat's-nest and mingles with the thick scent of wood-rot while the lark- song of a gutter-snipe echoes across a --

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR. DAY
dialogues.text: M. Gustave pushes a metal cart with a stack of plates and a steel tureen on it through a barred door. He stops in front of a large cell where four convicts loiter on their bunks playing cards, scratching graffiti on the walls, and looking at dirty pictures.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: May I offer any of you inmates a plate of mush? The convicts all look to M. Gustave at once. No one speaks. M. Gustave hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: No? Anyone? You -- with the very large scar on your face? M. Gustave points to a seven-foot giant with a deep slash from the top corner of his forehead all the way down and across to the other side of his chin. The giant frowns. He stands up. The other convicts look uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Come now. Try it. It’s, actually, quite warm and nourishing this morning. It needs a dash of salt. M. Gustave prepares a plate of lumpy gruel for the giant. He shakes-in a touch of salt from a shaker. The giant tastes it. Pause. He shrugs, pleased. He nods. M. Gustave smiles.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Good day. M. Gustave pushes his cart to the next cell. A bald wrestler lifts weights while an old man spots him.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Mush, gents? Any takers? The wrestler and the old man look at M. Gustave blankly with the barbell in the air. M. Gustave shrugs and says regretfully:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Suit yourselves.  53. M. Gustave pushes his cart to the next cell. These convicts are all asleep. M. Gustave says with a musical lilt:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Rise and shine. Chop-chop! A wiry, pint-sized convict the shape of a fire-hydrant squints out from under his covers. He is Pinky.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Pinky. Pinky yawns and sets his feet to the floor. The convicts in the other bunks also begin to rustle. Their faces are brutal, and their bodies are hard and powerful. They are Giinther and Wolf. (A fourth convict, also in the room, begins to get out of bed, as well -- but his face is not revealed for the moment.) M. Gustave reaches to the lower shelf of the cart and produces a pink pastry-box. All the convicts quickly gather at a small table. (The fourth convict sits with his back to the camera.) Pinky says eagerly:

dialogues.speaker: PINKY
dialogues.text: Mendl’s again?

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Precisely. Who’s got the throat-slitter? Giinther digs in his sock and takes out a small weapon consisting of a half-toothbrush fixed with wire to a hand-slivered straight-razor cut into serrated teeth. M. Gustave folds open the pastry-box and cuts a Courtesan au chocolat into careful segments. The convicts eat daintily. Wolf says, chewing

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Out of this world.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (obviously) Mendl’s is the best. Well, back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . Gustave rises. Pinky says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: PINKY
dialogues.text: Mr. Gustave?

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Yeah? Pinky exchanges a look with the others. They nod. He darts to the door, looks up and down the corridor, then  54. closes it softly. He signals for M. Gustave to sit back down. M. Gustave, slightly puzzled, obeys. They all lean in closer as Pinky whispers:

dialogues.speaker: PINKY
dialogues.text: Me and the boys talked it over. We think you're a real straight fella.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve never been accused of that before, but I appreciate the sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: PINKY
dialogues.text: You're one of us now.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (somewhat moved) What a lovely thing to say. Thank you, dear Pinky. Thank you, Giinther. Thank you, Wolf. I couldn't ask for a finer tribute. M,. Gustave bows slightly. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Anything else? Pinky looks to the fourth convict. He nods:

dialogues.speaker: PINKY
dialogues.text: Tell him, Ludwig.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The fourth convict. Numerous short scars chop skinny, bald lines into his shorn scalp. His arms are tattooed heavily with skulls, skeletons, and images of the grim reaper. He has one silver tooth and a bit of butter- cream icing on the side of his mouth. He is Ludwig. Ludwig takes a deep breath. He launches into his spiel:

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Check-point Nineteen ain’t no two-bit hoosegow. You got broad-gauge iron bars on every door, vent, and window. You got barb’ wire on every containment wall and barricade. You got seventy-two guards on the floor and sixteen more in the towers. You got a 325 foot drop into a moat full of crocodiles -- but, like the best of ‘em, it’s got a soft spot, which in this case happens to take the form of a storm- drain sewer-system datin’ from the time of the original rock fortification way back in the middle ages. Now, nobody’s (more)  55. LUDWIG (cont'd) sayin’ it’s a stroll down a tree-lined promenade with a fine lady and a white poodle, but it’s got what you'd call “vulnerability” -- and that’s our bread and butter. Take a look. Ludwig produces a crude but highly detailed map and floor-plan of the castle compound drawn with charcoal on a strip of butcher paper. M. Gustave examines it with fixed concentration. He says pointedly:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Who drew this?

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: (stiffening) What do you mean, “Who drew this?” I did.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (impressed) Very good. You've got a wonderful line, Ludwig. This shows great artistic promise. Ludwig smiles slightly, pleased and slightly embarrassed. M. Gustave points on the map:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Question: how do you intend to penetrate this lowest rudiment? If I interpret the legend correctly, it’s twenty-five inches of reinforced granite masonry, is it not? Digging with the throat-slitter, I expect that would take three to six months of continual effort, during which time several of our members will have been violently executed.

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: You hit the nail on the head there, Mr. Gustave. We got fake documents, second- hand street clothes, and a rope-ladder made out of sticks and bunk-linens -- but we need diggin’ tools, and that’s provin’ hard to come by in this flop-house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M. Gustave nods gravely. The others slump, listless, and sigh. M. Gustave taps rapidly on the table with the jerry-rigged shiv. Suddenly, he sits up straight and frowns. The others watch him, curious -- then look where he is looking.  56. The camera zooms-in slowly toward the crinkled wrapper of the Courtesan au chocolat as the five inmates all stare at it together.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Mr. Moustafa and the author at their dinner table surrounded by meats, sauces, and vegetables. Mr. Moustafa is immobile.

dialogues.speaker: AUTHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At this point in the story, the old man fell silent and pushed away his saddle of lamb. His eyes went blank as two stones. I could see he was in distress. “Are you ill, Mr. Moustafa?” I finally asked. “Oh, dear me, no," he said. “It’s only that I don’t know how to proceed.” He was crying. Mr. Moustafa smiles sadly with tears streaming down his cheeks. The author looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA
dialogues.text: You see, I never speak of Agatha, because -- even at the thought of her name -- I’m unable to control my emotions. Mr. Moustafa dries his eyes with his napkin, but the tears instantly return. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose there’s no way around it. You see, she saved us.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: One Month Earlier

dialogues.speaker: INT. CINEMA. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A smoky small-town movie palace. On-screen, a battle- scene is in-progress: tanks explode while an infantry unit charges out of a trench into a tornado of machine- gun fire. In the middle of the back row, a love-scene is in-progress: Zero and Agatha French-kiss in a clutch with her shirt half-unbuttoned and his fingers wrapped around her clearly-visible, white breast. Her hand is jammed down into his trousers. No one else in the Scattered audience appears to notice them.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On our third, formal rendez-vous, I had asked for her hand in marriage, and she had agreed. We did not have fifty Klubecks between the two of us. No one (more)  57. MR. MOUSTAFA (V.0.) (cont'd) knew, of course; but, then, who would have cared? We were each completely on our own in the world -- and we were deeply in love.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWN SQUARE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dusk. The platz in the center of Nebelsbad. A carnival fair is in full-swing with a spinning carousel set to a Wurlitzer organ, a bustling gallery of games, and vendors serving beer and sausages. Agatha holds Zero’s arm as they walk through the crowd. He reaches into his uniform, pulls out a small gift-wrapped package, and thrusts it into her hands.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: (startled) Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: It's a book.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I see.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: Romantic Poetry, Volume one. M. Gustave recommended it. I have a copy of my own as well. I ruined the surprise, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I'll go ahead and open it, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Agatha carefully unwraps the package, folds up the paper, and puts the ribbon into her pocket. Zero flips- open the book and points at a flyleaf.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: Read the inscription.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: (reading) “For my dearest, darling, treasured, cherished Agatha, whom I worship. With respect, adoration, admiration, kisses gratitude, best wishes, and love. From Z. to A.”  58. Agatha looks to Zero with tears in her eyes. He smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: M. Gustave insisted on an immediate and thorough cross-examination --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M. Gustave sits opposite Agatha at a long table with his hand resting on top of hers as he leans close to her recounting something vividly. They both laugh uproariously. M. Gustave says loudly, aside, to Zero:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: She's so charming! Zero broods in the corner. The table is piled with long- stemmed flowers, and a large, cardboard box overflows with more.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- during which he presented Agatha with a porcelain pendant and five dozen individually tissue-wrapped, white tulips in a box the size of a child’s coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white porcelain crossed-keys pendant hanging from a velvet ribbon around Agatha’s thin neck. Agatha admires her pendant. Zero grumbles:

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: It’s not right.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I beg your pardon? (conspiratorially to Agatha) Why’s he sulking?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: she’s my girlfriend. You can’t just buy her things.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (in disbelief) I’m only interviewing this vision of loveliness on your behalf (conveying pearls of wisdom) Never be jealous in this life, Zero. Not even for an instant.  59.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (to Agatha, like a lawyer:) Is he flirting with you?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: yes. Zero looks to M. Gustave with satisfaction. M. Gustave shrugs this off with a wave of the hand, then offers a benediction:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I approve of this union. (still flirting) Agatha, my beauty? Return to your beloved. Zero and Agatha stand together quietly on display, happy. She clutches a tulip. M. Gustave nods sagely.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Soon, we learned --

dialogues.speaker: INT. PATISSERIE. DAY
dialogues.text: The white-marble frosting-counter in the back-room at Mendl’s. There are three, unfinished Courtesans au chocolat in a row with their tops open. Agatha delicately places a little tool into the fillings of each: a slender file, the head of a small hammer, and a half-scale chisel. As she closes them, she begins to apply a complex series of decorative ripples and swirls.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: not only was Agatha immensely skilled with a palette knife and a butter-cream flourish: she was also very brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero, keeping a look-out at the kitchen door, gives an urgent signal. Agatha swiftly covers the pastries with a damp cheese-cloth just as Herr Mendl crosses into the room, throws open a huge brick-oven, and checks on a batch of gateaux 1’Opéra.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SORTING HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: A prison guard searches packages on a metal table. He slices a block of cheese into quarters. He chops-up a loaf of bread into sixths. He opens a double-sized pink pastry-box -- and pauses. He stares at the three pristine Courtesans au chocolat.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I believe she was born that way.  60. The guard gingerly closes the box, slides it aside, unscathed, and moves on to the next package.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LAWYER'S OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: An art-deco office looking out directly onto the clock- tower of Lutzbahn Station. Deputy Kovacs sits behind a wide desk. The box containing Madame D’s will rests beside him. Its contents have been neatly organized into dozens of little stacks and piles. Dmitri and his three sisters are seated across from Deputy Kovacs in leather arm-chairs. Jopling stands in the corner stroking a Siamese cat and staring out the window. Curtains sway in the gentle breeze. Deputy Kovacs sounds concerned:

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: Something's missing. A crucial document, either misplaced or, conceivably, destroyed. I don’t know what it contains, I don’t know what it represents, I don’t know what it is -- but there are traces and shadows of it everywhere. (motioning to the stacks of paper Now, I don’t want to alarm you, and I don’t expect to see any significant change in the magistrate’s ultimate decision vis-a-vis your own inheritance; but, especially given the circumstances of the death, as well as the disappearance of the key witness in the murder case (Serge X.), I suggest we immediately bring this matter to the attention of the municipal inspector so there can be absolutely no question of impropriety at any future date. Agreed?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: (simply) Not agreed.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Not agreed?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: (with finality) Not agreed. Silence. The three sisters are stoic. Jopling is stony. Dmitri and Deputy Kovacs stare at each other blankly.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question, Vilmos?  61.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: Yes, Dmitri?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Who you working for?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: I thought you're supposed to be our lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Well, in point of fact, I’m the executor of the estate. In this particular situation -- I represent the deceased.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: Yeah. A provision for my fees was included in the --

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Just wrap it up, and don’t make waves. Agreed?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: (long pause) I’m an attorney, Dmitri. I’m obligated to proceed according to the rule of law. Not agreed. Dmitri’s eyes peer sideways. He says quietly, menacing:

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: This stinks, sisters. Deputy Kovacs looks insulted. Dmitri stands up, walks to the door, and exits. The cat squeals. Jopling follows Dmitri out the door. Deputy Kovacs’ mouth falls open. He points, astonished, across the room:

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY KOVACS
dialogues.text: Did he just throw my cat out the window? The three sisters turn around quickly. They answer simultaneously:

dialogues.speaker: MARGUERITE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.  62.

dialogues.speaker: LAETIZIA
dialogues.text: Jopling?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: No. Did he? Deputy Kovacs waits for the punch-line -- but it does not come. He dashes to the window and looks down at the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A pedestrian in a bowler hat far below standing over a sprawled speck on the sidewalk. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four small hammers tap rapid-fire at four half-scale chisels, chipping away into a cement pot-hole. They are making good progress. INT. LUDWIG’S CELL. NIGHT M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, and Ludwig work diligently by candle-light under a wooden table. Periodically, Wolf scoops-up the powdery debris with a soup ladle and throws it aside. Ludwig looks up suddenly, alerted. He holds up a finger.

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Shh! M,. Gustave, Pinky, and Giinther stop tapping at once. They listen attentively. Feet creak along the thick, wooden floor outside the cell -- and come to a halt directly in front of the door. Silence. There is a loud but muffled sneeze. The feet begin to creak again and fade-away until they are inaudible. Ludwig signals to the others. They resume their tapping.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GARETT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: An attic bedroom the size of a broom-closet. The walls and ceiling are bare planks. Thick beams hold the crooked roof in place. A small skylight window is propped open with a pencil. Zero and Agatha are naked under the rough sheets of her narrow bed. They share a plate of little miniature Courtesans au chocolat. Zero whispers:  63.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: There's something I haven’t told you, Agatha. A look of dread crosses Agatha’s face. She says reluctantly:

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: We stole a painting. It’s very valuable (maybe five million Klubecks, in fact). I don't know if anyone’s even noticed it’s missing yet -- but if something should happen to me and M. Gustave --

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: (evenly) You stole -- art?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (defensive) One picture. Anyway: we need to make a plan for your survival. Hide this. Zero produces a square of tissue-paper the size of a large postage-stamp with neat, miniscule hand-writing all over it. Agatha squints at it.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: It’s in code, and you might need a magnifying glass to read it, but it tells you exactly where and how to find “Boy with Apple”. Don’t take less than half the retail asking price. Also --

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Zero. I'm a baker.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (correcting her) You're a pastry chef. One of the best in the --

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Not a “fence” (if that’s the term). I don’t trade in stolen property.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I said it wrong. She willed it to him!  64. A door bangs open down the hall. In an instant: Zero jumps out of the bed, leaps with both feet at once into his trousers, and shimmies up out of the sky-light.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zero’s point-of-view from the roof. The bedroom door creaks open and Herr Mendl looks in at Agatha. She is now calmly reading her volume of romantic poetry. He grunts:

dialogues.speaker: HERR MENDL
dialogues.text: Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Yes, Herr Mendl. The door closes. Agatha looks up to Zero. He holds up the sliver of paper. She shakes her head and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (pause) OK, but take it, anyway. Zero releases the square of tissue-paper. Agatha sits up quickly as it descends, darting and fluttering, and moves her hand around underneath it while she watches trying to estimate where it is going to land. At the last second, she reaches up and cleanly plucks it out of the air between thumb and finger. Zero smiles. He runs away, shoe-less, past gutters and chimneys, jumping noiselessly from roof to roof, into the night.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE BUILDING. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A bank of elevators in an art-deco lobby. A bell rings, and a pair of doors slides open. Deputy Kovacs emerges and navigates his way through a maze of suds-buckets and women on their hand-and-knees scrubbing the floor. He does not notice: Jopling sitting in a chair behind a column reading the evening edition of the Trans-Alpine Yodel.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The evening sky is bright blue. Crowds hurry in and out of shops and restaurants. Deputy Kovacs crosses the street and stands next to an old lady at a tram-stop. He checks his watch. The tram arrives, and the door opens.  65. Deputy Kovacs assists the old lady, then boards behind her. He takes a seat. He looks out the window. Just as they pull away, he sees Jopling exit the building and climb onto his motorcycle. Deputy Kovacs frowns. Jopling kick-starts his engine and follows the tram, close behind, for three blocks. At the next intersection, a policeman blows a whistle, holds up his hand, and makes Jopling wait while a stream of opposing traffic crosses. The tram rounds a corner and stops. Deputy Kovacs jumps up and ducks out onto the street. He looks left and xight. He hurries up a path toward a grand, colossal, domed palace. A sign carved in stone above the door reads: Kunstmuseum Lutz. As he goes inside, Deputy Kovacs looks back to see Jopling’s motorcycle pulling slowly to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MUSEUM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The spacious, soaring entrance hall is dim and deserted. One guard sits alone in a corner writing in a log-book. Deputy Kovacs strides across the room. His clacking feet echo broadly. He detours into an ante-chamber filled with French still-lives. He pauses. A second set of foot-steps clack through the lobby behind him. Deputy Kovacs advances rapidly into the next gallery, past a long mural of an ancient war, and descends a staircase. He pauses again at the bottom. The second set of foot-steps continues through the ante- chamber behind him. Deputy Kovacs turns a corner and rushes between rows of Greek and Roman statues. He cuts through an Egyptian tomb. He skims through an alcove of iron weapons and suits of armor. He pauses once more and listens. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of high-heeled boots. Two feet quietly slip out of them and tip-toe away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Deputy Kovacs looking all around, frantic. Across the room, he sees:  66. A door labelled VERBOTEN. Deputy Kovacs runs to the door and opens it. He scans the hall behind him. He sneaks inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STORAGE ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Deputy Kovacs flicks on a light. He is in a long hallway lined with racks filled with hundreds of canvases. The xoom goes dark at either end. He chooses a direction, then sprints straight through into the blackness. Up ahead, he sees lines of faint light around the edges of a door. He skids to a stop and searches for the knob. He turns it and pulls. It is locked. He fumbles at a latch. He snaps it sideways. He swings open the door. His eyes light up: There is a bicycle leaning against the wall across the alley behind the museum. Deputy Kovacs grabs the door- frame and takes one last, quick look back into the darkness behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy Kovacs’ hand on the knob. A second hand, wearing brass knuckles, gently enfolds it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Deputy Kovac’s face. He gasps.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The door hammers shut with a bang. Four of Deputy Kovacs’ fingers, gripping the door-frame, pop-off at the knuckles all at once and fall down into a shallow puddle. On the other side of the door, there is a scream of blood-curdling agony, then a thump, a thwhack, and, finally, a wallop. Pause. The door opens again. Jopling comes out in his stocking- feet. He puts on his boots. He takes out a handkerchief, leans down and collects the four fingers off the ground, wraps them up, slips them into his pocket, and walks away down the alley.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY. DAY
dialogues.text: Eight a.m. Zero, substituting at the concierge desk again, looks up to the high window across the room. Herr Becker waits alone in the storage pantry with the ledger book under his arm. He checks his watch.  67.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOUSTAFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The next morning, Herr Becker received a peculiar, last-minute-notice from the office of Deputy Kovacs: postponing their scheduled meeting -- in perpetuity.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Three Days Later

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VILLAGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A nearly-empty bus squeals to a stop behind a quiet inn in the middle of a deserted hamlet and deposits Zero on the road-side. He carries a knapsack and is dressed like a vagabond. The bus drives off. Zero wanders to the middle of the cobblestone lane. He looks down at a rusty manhole. He looks up at the prison- castle across the way, high above the village. He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, Wolf, and Ludwig all lie quietly in their bunks with the sheets pulled up to their necks. Faraway voices shout and echo eerily. A guard walks through the section slamming doors and throwing bolts. With a series of loud thumps, block-by- block, the lights go out, and the prison goes dark. Silence. Ludwig whispers:

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Let’s blow! The cell launches into soundless activity: bed-linens are whisked away, the table is carried into the corner, and a row of floor-planks is carefully lifted. M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, Wolf, and Ludwig are all dressed like vagabonds already and carry various sacks and baskets. One-by-one, they disappear into the floor. A pair of hands, at the rear, reaches up to replace the planks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CRAWL-SPACE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, Wolf, and Ludwig advance on all fours, single-file, through a low, moldy sub- structure.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOWER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A small window in a stone wall. Ludwig gently taps-loose four pre-cut iron bars with one of the small hammers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stump of one of the bars. A little noose is fitted over it and pulled tight. Giinther assists Ludwig as they slowly feed an unfurling tangle of rope and rungs out the window, inch-by-inch.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, Wolf, and Ludwig all on the rope-ladder at once like a string of beads dangling down the outside of the tower 325 feet above the moat with crocodiles gliding along the dark surface. The ladder twists and creaks as they descend. Suddenly, a sharp voice calls out above their heads:

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: How’d you get out there? They all look up. An anxious convict with a missing ear stares down at them from a cell window. Ludwig whispers:

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Shut up! The convict frowns. He turns to his unseen bunk-mates and says loudly:

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: These guys are tryin’ to escape! Ludwig looks furious. He whispers fiercely:

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you, you goddamn snitch?

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: (hollering) Guard! Guard! They’re gettin’ away! They're -- A single, large hand grabs the convict with the missing ear by the neck, crushes the wind out of him, and rips him away from the window, out of view. Pause. The giant with the long scar across his face appears in the convict’s place, looking down at the dangling escapees. M. Gustave says, gasping:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: It’s you! Thank you! Thank you, you sweet, kind man! The giant nods sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottom of the rope ladder which ends half-way down the tower. M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, Wolf, and Ludwig step onto a narrow ledge and make their way, side- stepping cautiously, around the circumference of the building. They arrive at a small sloped roof and open a trap-door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORMITORY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, Wolf, and Ludwig all crouch on a beam in the upper eaves of a vaulted hall. In the dark below, there are twenty narrow cots in two rows. Next to each cot, there is a guard’s uniform on a coat- hanger, a billy-club on a peg, and a Luger pistol on the night stand. Asleep in each cot, there is a lightly snoring goon. Ludwig gets a firm grip on a tarnished copper pipe. He turns to the others and nods. He swings out and makes his way, hand-over-hand, from pipe-to-pipe across the ceiling. The others follow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELLAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A dirty chute sticks down from the ceiling above a wide garbage-bin filled with empty tins and rotting vegetables. M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, Wolf, and Ludwig slide down into view, one-by-one, drop out into the trash-pile, and hurry on their tip-toes into a dim corridor.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The candle-lit dungeon. M. Gustave, Pinky, Giinther, Wolf, and Ludwig all listen attentively, looking up at the ceiling. There is a loud but muffled sneeze above, then feet creaking away. Ludwig nods. Pinky pulls away an oil-skin tarp to reveal the cement pot-hole which has now been chiselled all the way through the thick sub-floor clear into the room below -- where they see: Three startled guards staring up at them from a card table in a dank, brick basement. They each hold a hand of cards. One is in the middle of placing a bet into a rich pot. A gas-lantern flickers on a hook. The escapees all cry-out at once:

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Woah!

dialogues.speaker: PINKY
dialogues.text: Yow!  70.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Jeez!

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Look out! Giinther whips the toothbrush-knife out of his sock and jumps down into the hole. The table shatters and cards and coins fly in every direction. There is a frenzy of punching, scrapping, and grunting. The others converge excitedly around the hole like the audience at a cock- fight. Giinther kicks one guard in the teeth, slashes another across the neck, and socks the third, blasting the lantern into bits in the process. The room goes black. M. Gustave, Pinky, and Wolf cheer at a low decibel, whispering advice and encouragement simultaneously down into the darkness while Ludwig quickly searches for a match. He lights it and holds it over the hole. Two of the guards are now sprawled-out on their backs in a spreading pool of blood. Giinther and the remaining guard twist and clutch on the floor, grappling in violent head-locks, while they simultaneously stab each other repeatedly with the throat-slitter and a thick hunting-knife. They both fall silent and stop moving. Silence. M. Gustave says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I suppose you'd call that a draw. Ludwig sighs. He delivers a brief eulogy:

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Anyway, he went out with a bloody knife in his fist jammed into the gut of a dyin’ prison guard. I think that’s how he would’ve wanted it, don’t you? M. Gustave, Pinky, and Wolf nod and solemnly concur, muttering. They climb down into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Zero watches as the man-hole cover flips open onto the street. M. Gustave pokes his head up and whispers simply:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Good evening. Zero rushes to assist M. Gustave out of the storm-drain. Pinky, Wolf, and Ludwig surface on high-alert, looking  71. around in every direction. (Pinky carries a wad of the crumbled-up gambling-money in his little hand.)

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Let me introduce you. Pinky, Wolf, and Ludwig: this is the divine Zero. (soberly to Zero) Giinther was slain in the catacombs. M. Gustave crosses himself quickly. He begins a wistful speech:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Well, boys, who knows when we'll all meet again; but if, one day --

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: No time to gab. Take care of yourself Mr. Gustave. Good luck, kid. Pinky, Wolf, and Ludwig sprint away into the woods. M. Gustave watches them go, bittersweet. He grabs Zero by the shoulder and says, suddenly urgent:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Which way to the safe house?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (unfortunately) I couldn't find one.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (in disbelief) No safe house? Really? We're completely on our own out here?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (worried) I’m afraid so. I asked around, but I didn’t want to take any chances. I thought —- Zero trails off. He looks apologetic. M. Gustave sighs resigned. He says calmly:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I understand. Too risky. We'll just have to wing it, I suppose. Let’s put on our disguises. Zero hesitates. He looks down at his vagabond costume then at M. Gustave’s. He says, confused:

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: We're wearing them.  72.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) No, we're not. We said false whiskers and fake noses and so on. You didn’t bring any?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (referring to moustache) I thought you were growing one. It wouldn’t look realistic, would it? I thought

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero trails off again. He deflates, distressed. M. Gustave remains calm.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: When done properly, they're perfectly convincing -- but I take your point. So be it. Give me a few squirts of L’air de Panache, please, will you? Zero smacks his hand to his forehead and looks mortified. M. Gustave says bluntly:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Can I not get a squirt, even?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (miserably) I forgot the L’air de Panache.

dialogues.speaker: M,. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (at peak frustration) Honestly -- you forgot the L’air de Panache? I don’t believe it. How could you? I’ve been in jail, Zero! Do you understand how humiliating this is? I smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M. Gustave lifts up his arms. Zero sniffs him. He grimaces. M. Gustave’s eyes narrow. He begins to seethe.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s just marvelous, isn’t it? I suppose this is to be expected back in where do you come from, again?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (evenly) Aq Salim al-Jabat.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (escalating) Precisely. I suppose this is to be expected back in Aq Salim al-Jabat where one’s prized possessions are a stack of (more)  73. M. GUSTAVE (cont'd) filthy carpets and a starving goat, and one sleeps behind a tent-flap and survives on wild dates and scarabs -- but it’s not how I trained you. What on God’s earth possessed you to leave the homeland where you very obviously belong and travel unspeakable distances to become a penniless immigrant in a refined, highly- cultivated society that, quite frankly, could’ve gotten along very well without you?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) The war.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Say again? Zero speaks softly and struggles deliberately to hold back his emotions as he says, staring at the ground:

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: Well, you see, my father was murdered, and the rest of my family were executed by firing squad. Our village was burned to the ground. Those who managed to survive were forced to flee. I left -- because of the war.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (back-peddling) Ah, I see. So you're, actually, really more of a refugee, in that sense.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (reserved) Truly.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (ashamed) Well, I suppose I'd better take back everything I just said. What a bloody idiot I am. Pathetic fool. Goddamn selfish bastard. This is disgraceful -- and it’s beneath the standards of the Grand Budapest. Zero looks increasingly concerned as M. Gustave begins to come unglued. Tears stream down M. Gustave’s face. He stands at attention and says with deep deference:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I apologize on behalf of the hotel  74.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (gently) It’s not your fault, M. Gustave. You were just upset I forgot the perfume

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Don't make excuses for me. I owe you my life. M. Gustave takes Zero by the hand. He says with great feeling and sincerity:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: You're my dear friend and protégé, and I’m very proud of you. You must know that. I’m so sorry, Zero.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (gallantly) We're brothers. M. Gustave, touched to the quick, instantly kisses Zero on both cheeks and they embrace. They release each other. They try to pull themselves back together. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: How's our darling Agatha? Zero starts to answer, then hesitates. He recites: ZERO. “twas first light when I saw her face upon the heath; and hence did I return day-by-day, entranced: tho’ vinegar did brine my heart --” A powerful siren begins to blast across the region. Zero’s eyes dart around, startled. M. Gustave says over the noise, impressed:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Very good! I’m going to stop you because the alarm has sounded -- but remember where we left off, because I insist you finish later! M. Gustave and Zero take-off full-speed down the road.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TELEPHONE BOOTH. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A black-and-yellow wooden call-box next to a tiny pub outside the village. Windmills spin gently on the far side of a wheat field in the distance. Zero holds the door open while M. Gustave dials.  75.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Operator, get me the Excelsior Palace in Baden-Jiirgen and reverse the charges please. (to Zero) We've no choice. There’s nowhere else to turn. (into the receiver) I'll hold. Thank you. (to Zero) It’s our only hope. Otherwise, I shouldn’t even mention its existence to you. It goes without saying, you must never breath a word about this to a living soul. Do you swear?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: Of course. What is it, in fact?

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I can’t say. (into the receiver) Guten abend. M. Ivan, bitte. Danke. (by way of explanation, to Zero) How does one come by front-row aisle- seats for a first-night at the Opera Toscana with one day’s notice? How does one arrange a private viewing of the tapestry collection at the Royal Saxon Gallery? How does one secure a corner table at Chez Dominique on a Thursday? Zero nods as he takes this in, intrigued. Pause. M. Gustave says suddenly into the receiver, turning on the charm:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Ivan, darling, it’s Gustave! Hello! Well I was until about five minutes ago. We've taken it upon ourselves to clear out in a hurry, if you see what I mean. Through a sewer, as it happens. Exactly! Listen Ivan, sorry to cut you off, but we’re in a bit of a bind. This is an official request. (officially) I’m formally calling upon the special services of —-

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Part 4: “The Society of the Crossed Keys”  76.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIRST LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Concierge desk #1. There are rows of mail-boxes with xoom numbers on them, keys on hooks, and a bell on the counter-top. A slim concierge with a long moustache talks on the telephone. He is M. Ivan. A Lobby Boy waits beside him silently.

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: I'll call you back, Gustave. Right. Stand by. M. Ivan hangs up the telephone and turns to a waiting young couple as he produces a small paper map from a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon. Do you prefer to walk? We're right here. M. Ivan makes a little “x” in ink on the map. He draws a line.

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: It’s very simple. Straight down the corniche. Then left. (to the Lobby Boy) Jojo, see them out. The young couple take the map gratefully, and the Lobby Boy escorts them away. M. Ivan picks up the telephone again and says urgently:

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: Get me M. Georges at the Chateau Luxe, please.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The dining room at a hunting lodge. One hundred small children crowd around a long table. There is a huge birthday cake with seven lit candles on it. Streamers hang from the ceiling. Balloons float on strings. A very tall, bony concierge conducts the room singing “Happy Birthday”. He is M. Georges. A Lobby Boy goes over to M. Georges and whispers in his ear. M. Georges nods and quickly exits. The Lobby Boy replaces him and takes over the conducting

dialogues.speaker: INT. SECOND LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Concierge desk #2. M. Georges picks up the telephone.  77.

dialogues.speaker: M. GEORGES
dialogues.text: Hello, Ivan? You don’t say? Is he really? How about that? Got it. M. Georges presses down on the hook to disconnect, then lifts it up again and says urgently:

dialogues.speaker: M. GEORGES
dialogues.text: Get me M. Dino at the Palazzo Principessa, please.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A busy piazza across from a church. There is a crowded trattoria on the sidewalk. There is a statue of a centurion. One hundred men and women in pajamas and bath- robes stand on the street in front of a hotel looking up at a fourth-floor window with smoke gushing out of it while a ladder extends from a fire engine toward a calm old woman at the windowsill. An alarm rings loudly. A stocky concierge with slick, black hair stands at the front of the crowd yelling orders and holding a fire- extinguisher. He is M. Dino. A Lobby Boy goes over to M. Reggio and whispers in his ear. M. Dino nods and quickly goes into the hotel. The Lobby Boy takes the fire-extinguisher and replaces him yelling orders.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THIRD LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Concierge desk #3. The lobby is a bit smoky. M. Dino picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: M. DINO
dialogues.text: M. Georges. No trouble at all. Tell me. I see. I see. Straight away. M. Dino presses down on the hook to disconnect, then lifts it up again and says urgently:

dialogues.speaker: M. DINO
dialogues.text: Get me M. Robin at 1’Hétel Céte du Cap, please.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A clay tennis court overlooking a bright, blue sea at sunset. Twenty-five men and women in tennis whites and bathing suits circle around another tennis player lying flat on his back on the ground while a very fit, sporty concierge with a pompadour sits on one knee next to him checking his pulse. He is M. Robin. A Lobby Boy goes over to M. Robin and whispers in his ear. M. Robin nods and quickly leaves the court. The  78. Lobby Boy replaces him and resumes checking the fallen man’s pulse.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FOURTH LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Concierge desk #4. M. Robin picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: M. ROBIN
dialogues.text: This is M. Robin. Yes, Dino. Yes, Dino. Yes, Dino. OK, Dino. M. Robin presses down on the hook to disconnect, then lifts it up again and says urgently:

dialogues.speaker: M. ROBIN
dialogues.text: Get me M. Martin at the Ritz Imperial please.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: An extremely busy hotel kitchen filled with cooks of every rank and specialty. Waiters dash in and out continuously. A small, round concierge with a pink face is screaming and pointing a serving fork at the chef (who is flambé-ing a crépe suzette). He is M. Martin. A Lobby Boy goes over to M. Martin and whispers in his ear. M. Martin nods and quickly exits the kitchen. The Lobby Boy takes the serving fork and replaces him screaming at the chef.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIFTH LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Concierge desk #5. M. Martin picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: M. MARTIN
dialogues.text: Robin, Martin. I know. So I heard. (suddenly intrigued) Maybe. (gravely) Let me make a few calls.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WHEAT FIELD. NIGHT
dialogues.text: M. Gustave and Zero wait hidden behind a hay-stack next to the telephone booth. M. Gustave re-caps:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Serge X: missing. Deputy Kovacs: also missing. Madame D: dead. “Boy with Apple”: stolen (by us). Dmitri and Jopling: ruthless, cold-blooded savages. Gustave H: at large. what else?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: Zero: confused.  79.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (nodding) Zero: confused, indeed. The plot “thickens”, as they say. Why, by the way? Is it a soup metaphor?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Distant tires squeal. M. Gustave and Zero sit up quickly and peer-off down the xoad. An approaching car accelerates, whining in the darkness. A pair of head-lights pops into view from the woods. A large sedan emerges with a roar, zig-zagging onto the farm road. It slides across the gravel and rips to a stop in front of them. A sign next to five stars on the side of the hood reads: Hotel Excelsior Palace. One of the back doors snaps open, and M. Ivan shouts from inside:

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: Get in! M. Gustave and Zero dash out from behind the hay-stack and sprint to the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: The door slams shut, and the chauffeur punches it. They speed back into the hamlet. M. Ivan immediately begins briefing M. Gustave and Zero:

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: We found the butler. He’s hiding-out in the remote foot-hills near Gabelmeister’s Peak. Our contact convinced him to meet you mid-day tomorrow at the observatory on the summit. Tell no one. He’ll explain everything. The train departs in four-and- a-half minutes. Here’s your tickets. M. Ivan deals-out a pair of train tickets to M. Gustave and Zero. M. Gustave gives his a quick study, then mumbles a puzzled objection:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Third class?

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: It was over-booked, but the conductor used to be a sommelier at the old Versailles. He pulled some strings. You'll need these for the dining car.  80. M. Ivan produces two, pre-tied neck-ties. M. Gustave and Zero slip them over their heads and adjust the knots. The chauffeur hits the brakes, and M. Ivan swings the door open again.

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: Go!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAIN STATION. NIGHT
dialogues.text: M. Gustave and Zero jump out in front of a very small depot and slam the door. M. Ivan says out the window

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: One last thing. M. Ivan leans down and searches for something on the floor. He sits up and thrusts-out a tiny version of a familiar bottle. M. Gustave melts as he realizes:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: L’air de Panache!

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: (down-playing it) They only had the half-ounce. M. Gustave looks impressed and deeply touched. He leans to Zero and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: We should give him something as a symbolic gesture. How much money you got?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Forty-two Klubecks and three postage stamps.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Give me twenty-five. Zero’s eyes widen. He cocks his head, dubious. M. Gustave nods firmly. Zero reluctantly digs a handful of coins and bills out of his pocket and passes it on to M. Gustave. M. Gustave says to M. Ivan with profound gratitude:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Bless you. M. Gustave attempts to discreetly press the money into M. Ivan’s palm -- but M. Ivan withdraws. He waves his hands and says by way of gentle refusal  81.

dialogues.speaker: M. IVAN
dialogues.text: Please. M. Gustave smiles sadly. He bows. The hotel car skids away. Silence. M. Gustave sprays himself four times with the perfume atomizer. His posture and bearing immediately improve. He turns to Zero. Pause. M. Gustave holds out the bottle. Zero looks confused -. then simultaneously flattered and hesitant. He takes the cologne and spritzes himself once lightly. He gives a polite nod and returns the bottle. A train pulls into the station, and M. Gustave and Zero race out onto the platform.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A stack of wooden planks next to the opening in the cell floor. Ten guards and twenty soldiers stand crowded in the little room looking down at the hole. Henckel’s head pokes up from the crawl-space below. He wears a look of grim determination as he delivers the following:

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: I want roadblocks at every junction for fifty kilometers. I want railblocks at every train station for a hundred kilometers. I want fifty men and ten bloodhounds ready in five minutes. We're going to strip-search every pretzel-haus waffel-hut, biergarten -- and especially every grand hotel -- from Augenzburg to zilchbriick. These men are dangerous, professional criminals. (At least, three of them are, anyway.) Henckels hesitates. He squints across the room. He points.

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: Who are you? The guards and soldiers all turn to look past the bunks behind them and clear the view to: Jopling alone in the dim back corner.

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Civilian personnel aren’t permitted in the cell- block. This is a military investigation.  82. Jopling steps fully into view. A shifty guard explains nervously:

dialogues.speaker: SHIFTY GUARD
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Jopling, sir. His employer's mother was one of the victims of the --

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: Shut up. Henckels climbs up out of the hole as Jopling approaches and offers his card. Henckel snaps it up, gives it a fraction-of-a-second look, then hands it off to an underling.

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: You work for the family Desgoffe und Taxis? Pause. Jopling nods. Henckels asks pointedly:

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: Are you aware of the murder of Deputy Vilmos Kovacs on the twenty-third of October?

dialogues.speaker: JOPLING
dialogues.text: (carefully) I’m aware of his disappearance.

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: His body was found stuffed in a sarcophagus behind a storage room at the Kunstmuseum late last night. He was short four fingers. What do you say about that? Henckels withdraws a type-written document out of his coat. He holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police report with a photograph of Deputy Kovacs’ body in a pharaoh’s casket with his hands crossed on his chest. A section at the bottom of the page is labelled FINGERPRINTS. There are five for the left hand, but only a thumb for the right. Jopling studies the document. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: Escort Mr. Jopling off the premises. Jopling makes his way toward the cell door accompanied by several soldiers. He pauses just before he exits. He leans down and picks up a flattened, pink, cardboard box  83. off the floor. He scrapes a ridge of icing with his finger and licks the tip. He says softly:

dialogues.speaker: JOPLING
dialogues.text: Mendl's. Henckels watches Jopling suspiciously as he shrinks away down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dmitri, dressed in black pajamas and a black smoking jacket with a fur collar, listens on the telephone in a small alcove. He says calmly:

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Talk to his club-footed sister again -- and, this time: be persuasive. Dmitri hangs up. He crosses into the library and stands in front of a snooker table. The box containing Madame D’s will sits among billiard balls in the middle of it. Its contents have been spread-out and scattered into a sprawling mess. Marguerite, Laetizia, and Carolina play cards and sip at tiny glasses of port on the other end of the room. Dmitri drinks a vodka in one gulp. He shuffles and sifts among the scraps, preoccupied. He picks up a folded sliver of cream-colored writing-paper. He opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A page of Grand Budapest Hotel stationary with a set of crossed keys insignia at the top. Hand-written below is: Remember: I’m always with you Dmitri stares at the piece of paper. He tosses it back onto the table. It lands on top of a faded, old photograph of “Boy with Apple” with the stamp at the bottom of a long-defunct auction house. Dmitri frowns. He turns around and looks up at the wall above the fireplace directly behind him. His face goes white.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The wood-cut print of the two lesbians masturbating. A bit of the discolored wallpaper sticks out behind it on either side. Dmitri is stunned. He stammers:  84.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Holy fuck! What’s the meaning of this shit? Marguerite, Laetizia, and Carolina all look. They seem confused. They respond simultaneously:

dialogues.speaker: MARGUERITE
dialogues.text: “Boy with Apple”? I thought you'd hidden it.

dialogues.speaker: LAETIZIA
dialogues.text: It’s been missing two weeks. I assumed it went to the tax-appraiser.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: Why are you only noticing now? Dmitri shakes his head, speechless. He says finally, in angry shock:

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me? Clotilde has materialized. Dmitri turns to her. Marguerite, Laetizia, and Carolina turn to her, also. Clotilde’s voice cracks and quivers as she says:

dialogues.speaker: CLOTILDE
dialogues.text: I believe it was removed by M. Gustave. Pause. Dmitri grabs the wood-cut off the wall and slams it (punching a thick hole through the center) over a small marble discus-thrower.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A third-class compartment on the over-night to Gabelmeister’s Peak. Students, peasants, and laborers sleep among rucksacks and baskets on hard benches and shelves lining the walls. M. Gustave and Zero whisper to each other from their bunks near the ceiling on either side of the room:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I’m not angry with Serge. You can’t blame someone for their basic lack of moral fiber. He’s a frightened, little, yellow- bellied coward. That’s not his fault, is it?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It depends.  85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) Well, you can say that about most anything. “It depends.” Of course, it depends. ZERO. (firmly) Of course, it depends.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (sighs) Yes, I suppose you’re right. Of course it depends. However: that doesn’t mean I'm not going to throttle the little swamp rat. (pause) May I officiate, by the way? The ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (surprised, humbly) With pleasure. M. Gustave sighs. He says with deep sincerity and feeling:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I must say, I find that girl utterly delightful. Flat as a board, enormous birthmark the shape of Mexico over half her face, sweating for hours on end in that sweltering kitchen while Mendl (genius though he is) looms over her like a hulking gorilla -- yet without question, without fail, always, and invariably: she’s exceedingly lovely. Why? Because of her purity.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (pleased) She admires you, as well, M. Gustave.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (perking up) Does she?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: very much.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (impressed) That’s a good sign, you know. It means she “gets it”. That’s important.  86.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (pause) Don’t flirt with her. M. Gustave scoffs, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GARRET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Agatha’s room. Her few possessions are laid-out neatly on the mattress: two changes of clothes, a short stack of cook-books, her volume of romantic poetry, some tangled ribbons, and a hairbrush. Agatha reaches up to the top of a skinny, pine wardrobe and pulls down an old, wicker suitcase. It has been repaired extensively with wire and string. She transfers everything she owns into it swiftly. She buckles it shut, slides it under the bed -- then bolts upright. She looks up at the ceiling. There is a thump. Silence. Agatha slips-off her shoes (wooden clogs). she slowly steps up onto the bed. She stands on her tip- toes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROOF. NIGHT
dialogues.text: There is no moon, and the night is pitch-black. Agatha’s hands grip the edges of the sky-light’s frame. Her eyes come up into view. She looks cautiously around in every direction. She listens. Agatha sinks back down, pulls away the pencil holding the sky-light window open, and quickly latches it shut. The camera holds on the empty roof-top: a quiet wind whistles over the sleeping village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front page of the Trans-Alpine Yodel. Headline: Young Girl’s Head Found in Laundry Basket

dialogues.speaker: INT. COMMAND HEAD-QUARTERS. DAY
dialogues.text: The next morning. An office decorated with flags, shields, and swords. There is a large map on a broad table with game pieces (chess, checkers, jacks, dice, and dominoes) marking troops and munitions. Henckels sits in a leather armchair drinking a cup of coffee while he stares at the front page of the newspaper. A first lieutenant stands over him holding a note-book and an envelope labelled WIRE MESSAGE. He explains:  87.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: A radio telegram was delivered and signed for by the girl at four a.m. The envelope was found near the body, but its contents were missing -- however: the telegraph office always keeps a carbon of the ticker-tape for twenty-four hours. I copied it down. It reads as follows: “pack your things stop be ready to leave at moment’s notice stop hide-out is vicinity of Gabelmeister’s Peak stop destroy this message all my love full stop.”

dialogues.speaker: HENCKELS
dialogues.text: (pause) Where’s the basket? The lieutenant points across the room. Henckels sighs. He stands up and walks over to a laundry basket on top of a desk against the wall. Pause. He reaches into it and lifts out, by the hair: Serge’s sister's severed head.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Part 5: “Gabelmeister’s Peak”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio telegram -- which has been torn to shreds, then carefully taped back together. It is speckled with blood.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GAS STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: A lone fuel-pump in front of a service-shack at the foot of hill on a snowy, country road. A fourteen-year-old attendant in a greasy jumpsuit fills the tank of Jopling’s motorcycle. A sled-runner has been fitted over the front wheel. Jopling leans against the wall, silent, looking down at the radio telegram in his hands. The attendant chirps:

dialogues.speaker: PUMP ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Where you headed, mister? Pause. Jopling’s eye-balls turn to the attendant.

dialogues.speaker: PUMP ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Skiing? Sledding? Mountain climbing? Jopling looks away again.  88. The attendant grows slightly uneasy. Jopling reaches into his leather coat -- half-revealing, holstered inside: a stiletto ice-pick, a black-jack bludgeon, a Luger pistol, and a ball-peen hammer. He withdraws a glass flask with a silver stopper and takes a pull. His brass knuckles clack against it The attendant clears his throat, pulls the nozzle out of the tank, and says -- polite but quick:

dialogues.speaker: PUMP ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Three Klubecks, please.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAIN STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: The Zubrowkian Alps. A high-altitude depot nestled in a pass between two, craggy ridges. There is fresh powder on the ground. Scattered flakes flicker in the air. A sign along the tracks reads: Gabelmeister’s Peak. Twenty-five soldiers armed with carbine rifles stand spaced apart down the length of the platform, waiting. The train rolls in. Doors open, and passengers with skis, snowshoes, and suitcases step down and hurry into the building and around its sides. The soldiers study them, attentive, and peer inside the compartment windows. The passengers continue until they have all cleared-away, and the platform is quiet again. A train conductor, leaning out from the end of a car, watches the soldiers. The soldiers look to each other tentatively. A Sergeant jerks open a door and steps onto the train. He looks around. He raises his chin, lifts his nose -- and sniffs the air. He looks irritated.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OBSERVATORY. DAY
dialogues.text: The peak of an icy butte. A narrow, domed building sticks up into the sky at the top. A steel balcony winds around it with a platform that extends out over a plunging drop into the white mist. A group of scientists bundled in fur coats listens to a professor. A man on a bench pours cocoa from a thermos. An eagle circles overhead. M. Gustave and Zero shiver at the end of the railing.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: It’s a hell of a view. I give them that, for what it’s worth.

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: I agree.  89. Pause. M. Gustave checks his watch. He says with a slightly bitter edge to his voice:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: When one says “mid-day” -- what does that mean to you?

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: High noon.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Exactly. In other words, twelve p.m. At least, that’s always been my interpretation. Silence. M. Gustave withdraws the small bottle of cologne from his pocket, spritzes himself twice, hands it to Zero who does the same automatically, then tucks it back away again. He holds-out his palm under the snow. He begins to recite:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: “'is oft’-remarked: no single, falling- flake does any other in its pure and perfect form --”

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: (tensely) Somebody's coming. A monk in a grey cloak and a thick scarf clanks up a metal staircase. His face is old and wrinkled. He walks directly out to M. Gustave and Zero and stops. He studies them for a moment, frowning. He whispers:

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Are you M. Gustave of the Grand Budapest Hotel in Nebelsbad?

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Get on the next cable-car. The monk points. A cable-car is just arriving down the sloping line from an adjacent peak. M. Gustave hesitates. The monk urges him on with a brusque motion. M. Gustave and Zero sprint across the balcony, scramble down a flight of steps, and race out onto the boarding platform. A family of six waits in skiing costumes. They stare at M. Gustave and Zero as they arrive, breathless. A tramway operator holds open the door. Everyone boards, squeezing.  90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cable-car sets-off up and across the wide ravine. M. Gustave and Zero sit side-by-side with the curious, silent family. The father sniffs the air. He looks irritated. Half-way there: the cable-car slams to a stop with a clunk. Everyone is startled. The stalled vehicle sways in the quiet wind. The father looks up. The mother looks down. The children look to each other. In the distance: there is a faint, mechanical hum. M. Gustave and Zero look out. Another cable-car is ascending at a diagonal on a different line. They all watch as it slowly approaches. Just as it is about to criss-cross their path: it slams to a stop, too. Another elderly, cloaked monk stares out from inside the other cable-car. He is alone in the vehicle. He studies M. Gustave and Zero for a moment, frowning. He whispers loudly:

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Are you M. Gustave of the Grand Budapest Hotel in Nebelsbad?

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Switch with me. The monk unlatches the door of his cable-car and opens it. The family watch nervously as M. Gustave and Zero stand up, rocking the vehicle, open their own door, and carefully exit. They reluctantly lunge across the precarious abyss. The monk changes places with them. There is another clunk, and the two cable-cars resume their journeys. M. Gustave and Zero exchange a look. Their new cable-car continues up toward its destination. A sign above the arrival platform reads: Our Holy Father of the Sudetenwaltz. Directly below it, there is a walled fort with a steeple and a tall stone cross. Another tramway attendant holds the door open for them as they disembark.  91.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MONASTERY. DAY
dialogues.text: M. Gustave and Zero walk down a staircase and through the front gate into an empty church-yard. There are walls and low buildings on the sides, a few graves in the middle, and the entrance to a church at one end. Pause. A small window swings open next to M. Gustave and Zero. Another elderly, cloaked monk stares out from inside a caretaker’s booth. He studies them for a moment, frowning. He whispers:

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Are you M. Gustave of the Grand Budapest Hotel in Nebelsbad?

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Put these on and sing. The monk thrusts a small bundle into M. Gustave’s hands. It consists of: two cloaks and two hymnals. The echoing sound of a Gregorian chant begins to rise from all around. M. Gustave and Zero swiftly slip-on the cloaks just as a procession of a hundred monks enters from two directions, merges in the church-yard, and advances double-file toward the chapel. M. Gustave and Zero open their hymnals at random and slip into the procession.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHURCH. DAY
dialogues.text: A blasting organ joins the chant inside a vast, austere hall as the procession enters. The monks file into pews. The music ends, and the room goes silent. Everyone kneels. The monsignor at the altar places his hands on a thick Bible and speaks Latin. A voice behind M. Gustave and Zero says:

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Psst. M. Gustave and Zero turn around. Another elderly, cloaked monk kneels on a kneeler behind them with his hands folded in prayer. He studies them for a moment, frowning. He whispers:

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Are you M. Gustave of the --  92.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (irritated) Yes, dammit.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Confess. M. Gustave looks deeply offended and flabbergasted. He snaps:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I’m innocent.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: (annoyed) No, no. The monk points to a confessional booth in the transept. M. Gustave hesitates. He nods, realizing. He and Zero look down the row of kneeling legs. They step up onto the pew, slink quickly in a crouch to the aisle, then hop down to the floor. Monks, watching them, frown. M. Gustave and Zero hurry together into the confessional booth and close the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONFESSIONAL. DAY
dialogues.text: A dark, wooden box lined with purple velvet. It is a bit tight for two. A panel slides open. Through the lattice screen: Serge has aged a decade. His eyes are watery and dim. He whispers immediately, reverent:

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: Forgive me, M. Gustave. I never meant to betray you. They threatened my life, and now they've murdered my only family.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) No! Who'd they kill this time?

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: (deeply wounded) My dear sister.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (trying to picture her) The girl with the club-foot?

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Those fuckers.  93.

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: I tried to warn you. At the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I know, darling. Let’s put that behind us. Listen: I hate to put you on the spot, but I really must ask you to clear my name. Obviously, you're grieving, and if I had any other --

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: There’s more.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) OK.

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: To the story.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: I get it. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: I was the official witness in Madame D’s presence to the creation of a second will to be executed only in the event of her death by murder.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: A second will.

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: In case she got bumped-off.

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: But they destroyed it.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Oh, dear.

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: However.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?  94.

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: I pulled a copy.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: (beat) A second copy of the second will

dialogues.speaker: SERGE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh? Long pause. M. Gustave finally starts to lose his composure. His voices rises:

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Well, what does it say? Where is it? What’s it all about, dammit? Don’t keep us in suspense, Serge. This has been a complete fucking nightmare. Just tell us what the fuck is going on The panel snaps shut. M. Gustave and Zero frown. The organ blasts again outside the confessional, and the church booms with low, eerie, singing voices. M. Gustave tries to jerk the panel open, but it sticks. He bangs on it with his fists.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Serge? Serge? Serge! M. Gustave tries the door. It is locked. Zero peers at the keyhole and says shortly:

dialogues.speaker: ZERO
dialogues.text: Give me the pass-keys. M. Gustave hesitates. He reaches into his pocket and pulls out his ring of Grand Budapest pass-keys. Zero rapidly flips through them, studying each key. He settles on one, inserts it into the keyhole, jiggles it, and twists. The lock clicks.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: M. Gustave and Zero jumping out from the confessional booth. Zero darts to the other side and cracks open the other door. He peeks-in and sees: Serge with a bloody garotte-wire strung around his neck. His eyes are wide-open, and his tongue sticks-out slightly. Zero grimaces. M. Gustave looks over his shoulder.  95.

dialogues.speaker: M. GUSTAVE
dialogues.text: Bloody hell. They've strangled the poor slob! M,. Gustave presses the door quietly shut again. He and Zero both look frantically around the room. One lone monk swings a smoking censor as he recesses quickly down the center aisle while the rest of the congregation stand in their pews singing. He steps outside and ducks away around the corner. M. Gustave and Zero’s eyes light up -- then narrow fiercely. They run after the monk.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COURTYARD. DAY
dialogues.text: M. Gustave and Zero dash out the front doors. They skid to a stop and scan the area. There is a display next to the church entrance of a wooden saint on a sled being pulled by a papier-maché reindeer. There is no one else in sight. A door creaks slowly in the wind outside a small shed across the way. A sign above it reads: Ski Locker (Clerical Use Only).
